journal-meta.journal-title: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control

title-group.article-title: A robust adaptive control for micro-positioning of piezoelectric actuators with environment force estimation

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
2New Technologies Research Center (NTRC), Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
3Department of Engineering Design and Manufacture, Faculty of Engineering, University Malaya, Malaysia

author-notes.corresp: H Ghafarirad, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran Email: Ghafarirad@aut.ac.ir

abstract.p: Piezoelectric actuators are widely used for precise micro-positioning. In most applications, there is contact with the environment. Sensing external forces is a challenging problem in controlling mechanical systems, especially in micro scales. The external force could cause dual hysteresis non-linearity effects, which will disrupt the actuator positioning accuracy. Therefore, an effective controller should be designed to guarantee the trajectory tracking in the presence of external forces and perturbations. In this paper, a modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii operator and its inverse is utilized for both identification and real time compensation of the hysteresis effect. A variable structure controller is proposed for trajectory tracking of the actuator position. A sliding-based observer would estimate full states from the only measurable position trajectory. An adaptive perturbation estimation approach is proposed so that external forces can be separated from disturbances. The stability of the controller in the presence of estimated states and external forces is demonstrated analytically. The experimental results depict that the proposed approach achieves precise trajectory tracking and good external force estimation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Piezoelectric actuators are widely used for fine positioning because of their specific properties such as high resolution, natural frequency and frequency response (Putra, 2008), but precision control of smart actuators such as piezoelectric actuators is a challenging problem. The major part of research work reported has been concentrated on the hysteresis non-linearity effect. There are different approaches considered for position control in free and constrained motions.

Preisach (Hughes and Wen, 1997), Krasnosel’skii–Pokrovskii (Krasnoselskii and Pokrovskii, 1989), Prandtl–Ishlinskii (Brokate and Sprekels, 1996), Duhem (Visintin, 1994) and Bouc–Wen (Ang et al., 2007) models have been proposed for identification of hysteresis effects. Applying the inverse hysteresis models as a feedforward compensator, position control of such actuators is carried out (Garcia-Valdovinos et al., 2007). Several methods have also been suggested for free motion micro-positioning control. Impedance control (Garcia-Valdovinos et al., 2007), sliding mode control (Bashash and Jalili, 2007) and robust control coupled with adaptive approaches (Bashash and Jalili, 2009; Li and Xu, 2009) have been derived in such a case. The main restriction is the assumption that full states of the actuator such as position and velocity are available, but in fact, the only measurable state is position.

A challenging control problem appears when contact with the environment occurs and an external force is presented. The induced environmental forces could disarrange the positioning and the control structure, but in piezoelectric actuators, these forces have an extra undesired effect too. The external forces could generate a reverse induced voltage that has also a hysteretic behaviour. This voltage could interfere with the actuator activation voltage. Therefore, a backward hysteresis effect (BHE) has a role of an extra perturbation in the system.

Small forces in micromanipulation pose a challenge on the design and construction of sensors that can provide measurements with high resolution and accuracy (Zhe, 2008). Instead of expensive force sensors, estimation algorithms for contact forces have been widely developed. Different approaches have been reported for the disturbance estimation. Considering the error in the actuator position estimation with a linear observer, Alcocera et al. (2003) presented an external force estimation approach based on the estimation error. Also, Abidi et al. (2004) proposed an observer based on a similarity in dynamics of the system and observer. A new force estimation method by eliminating the system uncertainties effect has been introduced by Bhattacharjee et al. (Bhattacharjee et al., 2008; Son et al., 2010).

However, the mentioned approaches have not taken into account any dynamic error for the proposed observers. This means that the stability of the observer and controller should be proved separately. As a result, stability of the overall system and controller structure in the presence of estimated forces could not be analytically proved. Daly et al. (Daly and Wang, 2009a; Daly, 2010) proposed a sliding-based disturbance observer with the consideration of the error dynamic. The major problem is that all the external forces and perturbations are observed together.

In this paper, a generalized Prandtl–Ishlinskii model and its inverse is utilized for identification and online feedforward compensation of hysteresis. This leads to the actuator dynamic model being transformed to the second-order linear dynamic model. Considering the BHE, parametric uncertainties, PI estimation error and probably unmodelled dynamics, a variable structure controller is proposed for trajectory tracking. A sliding-based observer would estimate full states from the only measurable position trajectory. An adaptive perturbation estimation approach is proposed to estimate pure external forces separately. The stability of the controller in the presence of estimated states and the environment force is demonstrated with the Lyapunov criterion. Finally, experimental results demonstrate that the proposed controller achieves precise trajectory tracking and good external force estimation.

sec.title: Observer-based robust adaptivecontrol with environment forceestimation
sec.p: A general non-linear dynamic system in contact with the environment is represented as:

where X=[x1,x2,…,xm] is the vector of m generalized co-ordinates. X(i)=[x1(i),x2(i),…,xm(i)] is the ith time derivative of the generalized co-ordinates. u(t) is the input and Fe would be external forces.
Because of parametric uncertainties, unmodelled dynamics and identification errors, the dynamic is described as

f
, b are the known parts and f~, b~ are the unknown parts of F and B, respectively (Zeinali and Notash, 2010). The dynamic model would be deduced as
Total uncertainties are represented as P(t). Defining d(t) as all unknown inputs and disturbances, the dynamic model of the system would be simplified as Equation (4).

The objective is accurate trajectory tracking of generalized co-ordinates. Designing the control structure, disturbances data are necessary. Instead of using a force sensor, an estimation approach could observe disturbances d(t). A proposed adaptive algorithm could estimate the perturbation term P(t) separately. As a result, the pure external force would be obtained.

sec.title: Robust control with adaptive perturbationestimation for a general non-lineardynamical system
sec.p: Due to uncertainties, a robust control such as sliding mode control could guarantee the exact performance of the system. Therefore, the sliding hyperplane and tracking errors are defined as

S
is an n×1 vector and K(i) is an n×n diagonal positive definite constant matrix.
Substituting the dynamic model to the time derivative of the sliding hyperplane, the control input is designed.
For simultaneous trajectory tracking and robustness, the control input would be proposed as

P
^
( t )
is the estimated perturbation.
Applying the proposed control input, the closed-loop dynamic error of the system is as follows.

Theorem 1. Utilizing the robust control input (7), the adaptive perturbation estimation law P^·=−ΓbTS could guarantee the asymptotically stability of closed-loop dynamic system and convergence of the slowly time-varying estimated perturbation.

Proof. The positive definite Lyapunov function candidate V=12STS+12P~TΓ-1P~ would be considered. Substituting the control input (7) and the proposed adaptive law in the time derivative of the Lyapunov function:

Negative semi-definiteness of V· guarantees the boundedness of the Lyapunov function and its parameters. Also V· would be uniformly continuous. Considering the non-autonomous dynamical system and the Barbalat lemma, V· would tend to zero as t→∞ (Slotine and Li, 1991).
The convergence of the estimated perturbation could also be guaranteed.

sec.title: Observer-based robust control with contact force estimation for a general non-linear dynamical system
sec.p: The proposed robust controller depends on the position and velocity states and external forces. With limitations on velocity and force sensors, a full state observer with the capability of disturbance estimation is essential. The observer in Daly and Wang (2009b) could be used in this research work but with some modifications. The proposed observer would estimate all external disturbances containing both external forces and perturbations. The major problem is caused by large existing perturbations. In such a case, the estimated disturbance is taken away from pure external forces. The innovation is concentrated in proposing an approach to estimate the perturbation separately and import it to the disturbance observer structure. As a result, the pure external forces could be estimated.
The states of the dynamic model (4) are assumed as
Therefore, the dynamic model is represented as (11).
The structure of the represented observer (Daly and Wang 2009b) is as follow
where P^(t) is the estimated perturbation term. X~i=X^i+(λi-1sgn(Xi−1−X^i−1))eq and (.)eq refers to the low pass filter. Ei=0 if Xi−X^i=/0. Otherwise, it would be as Ei=1.
To eliminate the effect of perturbation, the proposed observer is modified as follows.

With the original observer, all the disturbance would be estimated as (F^e+P^)=b−1(λnsgn(X~n−X^n)). Based on the modified observer structure, the estimated disturbance could be gained as (F^e+P~)=b−1(λnsgn(X~n−X^n)). This could be a more precise estimation of environmental forces. The stability of the observer is proved analytically, as in Daly and Wang (2009b) but the perturbation term P^ should be estimated.
The observer error dynamic is achieved by (11) and (13).

Δ f
and Δb are the variations in f and b caused by actual and estimated states.
Based on estimated estates, the controller should be modified. Therefore, the new sliding hyperplane and error signals are assumed as:
The revised controller is applied by new states as follows:
Adding ±X^(n) to the left side of the dynamic model (4), it could be arranged as:
Utilizing the observer error dynamic (14) and the proposed controller (16), the closed-loop dynamic would be gained simply as:

Because of the boundedness of b, it has been analytically proved that after a finite time the estimation error would tend to zero, thus Δb=0 (Daly and Wang, 2009b). As a result, the closed-loop dynamic is represented as

Theorem 2. Utilizing the robust control input (16) and assuming perturbation estimation P^·=−ΓbTS^, the asymptotically closed-loop stability of non-linear uncertain dynamic system would be guaranteed. Also the perturbation convergence in the presence of the estimated state is achieved.
Proof. Choosing the positive definite Lyapunov function candidate V=12S^TS^+12P~TΓ-1P~ and by utilizing control input (16), its time derivative would be obtained as
Because of non-autonomous dynamics, V· is negative semi-definite. Therefore S^ would be bounded. The second time derivative of the Lyapunov function is as follows:
This is bounded and V· would be uniformly continuous. As in Theorem 1, the convergence of perturbation would be guaranteed.

Remark 1. Assume that slow time-varying perturbations could be released with fast time-varying perturbations. In such a case, ultimately boundedness and convergence of tracking error to a small vicinity of origin could be analytically achieved. It was claimed that the proposed perturbation estimator with appropriate gain can successfully track the time-variant complex disturbances (Zeinali and Notash, 2010).

As a result, the designed controller guarantees precise trajectory tracking for the piezoelectric actuator. A modified disturbance observer estimates all disturbances existing in the control structure. With an adaptive perturbation estimation approach, the pure external force is obtained separately.

sec.title: Controller design for a micro-positioning piezoelectric actuator
Full dynamic model of piezoelectric actuators
sec.p: A second-order dynamic has been utilized for piezoelectric actuators. The model was divided into two parts. The first part is a second-order linear dynamic that refers to the mass-spring-damper system. The second part describes the non-linear portion of the dynamic, i.e. the hysteresis non-linearity effect.
Figure 1 shows the linear second-order dynamic of the piezoelectric actuator that would be added by the hysteresis non-linearity effect in the input.

caption.p: Second-order non-linear dynamic model of the piezoelectric actuator.

sec.p: Governing equation in free motion is represented as (22)

where x(t) and v(t) represent the actuator displacement and input voltage. m, c and k denote mass, damping and stiffness gains respectively. HF(v(t)) expresses the hysteretic relation between the input voltage and the excitation force.

Having high stiffness, the piezoelectric actuators possess high natural frequency. Due to this high natural frequency, in the low frequency operation the inertia and damping effects could be neglected. Hence (22) can be transformed to (23) in the free motion.

This equation relates the input voltage and actuator displacement together. By this facilitation, the constraint of identification of the voltage–force non-linear hysteretic relation is not necessary. As a result, the non-linear relation of input voltage and displacement would be identified. This means that the necessity of an accurate force sensor can be converted to the actuator position signal.
By identification of the hysteresis mapping between the input voltage and the actuator displacement (Hx(v(t))), it is scaled up with a factor k to obtain HF(v(t)).
In many cases, there is a contact force. Contacting with the environment would change the dynamic model by two terms as shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: (a) Dynamic model contacting with an environment (BHE); (b) forward and backward hysteresis loop.

sec.p: Figure 2(a) shows that two terms, contact force and BHE, are added to the dynamic. Forward and backward hysteresis relations are described in Figure 2(b) for the actuator contacting with the environment.
First, an external force term is added to the dynamic model.

F
e
is the external force imported by the environment.

Second, piezoelectric actuators have an extra hysteresis effect caused by the existence of external forces. This means that external forces could induce a reverse voltage on the actuator. Similarly to the forward hysteresis loop between actuated voltage and position, the induced voltage has a similar loop shape, as shown in Figure 3. This effect is the same BHE in this paper. An experiment was carried out to validate BHE. A piezoelectric actuator is derived by a harmonic voltage and its stack is connected to the force sensor. The other side of the force sensor could actuate a second piezoelectric actuator. The induced voltage and position data was gathered by a data acquisition card. The experimental set-up for achieving the BHE is seen in Figure 3(a). The backward hysteresis loop, which defines the non-linear relation between external force and induced voltage position is shown in Figure 3(b).

caption.p: (a) Experimental set-up for achieving the BHE; (b) BHE results related to contacting with the environment.

sec.p: The BHE would be considered a perturbation term in piezoelectric actuators. Considering BHE, parameter uncertainties, hysteresis estimation error and probably unmodelled dynamics, a perturbation term P(t) was added to the dynamic model. Finally, the dynamic model of the system is as follows:

sec.title: Generalized Prandtl–Ishlinskii (PI) hysteresis model
sec.p: A generalized Prandtl–Ishlinskii model is used for both hysteresis identification and compensation (Zareinejad et al., 2009). The most important advantage of this model is its simplicity and the fact that its inverse could be calculated analytically. In addition, this approach could be utilized in open-loop systems where the feedback of signals is not accessible.

The key idea of an inverse feedforward compensation of hysteresis is to cascade the inverse hysteresis operator Hx−1 with the actual hysteresis. As a result, an identity mapping between the desired actuator output xd(t) and the actuator response x(t) would be obtained. The structure of the inverse feedforward hysteresis compensation is shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Inverse feedforward compensation of the hysteresis effect. Reproduced with kind permission from Elsevier (Ghafarirad et al., 2011).

sec.p: In fact, the inverse PI model linearizes the non-linear dynamic system. For low frequency desired trajectories, the dynamic model is such as (23). So, Hx−1 would be used to linearized the system. As shown in Figure 4, the inverse PI operator Hx−1 uses xd(t) as an input and transforms it into a control input v=H−1(xd), which produces x(t) in the hysteretic system that closely tracks xd(t). As a result, feedforward positioning of the actuator for low frequency trajectories is achieved. In fact, the inverse PI model linearizes the non-linear dynamic system. For low frequency desired trajectories, the dynamic model is such as (23). So, Hx1 would be used to linearized the system.

Utilizing the control input (32), the adaptive perturbation estimation as P^·(t)=−ks^ and the positive definite Lyapunov function candidate V=12(s^2+12kP~2) is proposed. Therefore, based on Theorem 2, the asymptotically stability of dynamic system in the presence of estimated states and external forces would be guaranteed.
Figure 5 shows the overall block diagram of the proposed observer-based sliding mode control with adaptive perturbation estimation and external force estimation.

caption.p: The block diagram of closed-loop system.

sec.title: Experimental results
sec.p: The proposed controller was verified experimentally. The experimental set-up contains a PI 611.1S piezoelectric actuator in contact with a loadcell as the environment. The piezoelectric actuator is shown in Figure 6.

caption.p: The piezoelectric actuator in contact with the environment.

sec.p: Matlab/Simulink software is utilized for implementation of the control approach. A DS1104 dSPACE data acquisition card and controller board are used for data the capturing. The experimental set-up is shown in Figure 7.

The control scheme was designed in Simulink and the control input is sent to the actuator driver by a D/A. The sampling frequency is set to be 1 kHz. A strain gauge would feed back the position of the actuator.

The multi frequency desired trajectory would be xd=37+12sin(10t)+8sin(8t)+6sin(9t). Since the actuator is in contact with the environment primarily, a periodic external force is exerted with the frequency of the input. The external force and its estimation with the suggested approach are shown in Figure 8.

As mentioned before, there are dual hysteresis effects. The first one is in deriving the piezoelectric, between the input voltage and actuator output. Utilizing the modified PI model, the hysteresis was identified. Figure 9 depicts the normalized effect of hysteresis compensation by the inverse PI model in the presence of environment force.

caption.p: Hysteresis compensation in the presence of external force.

sec.p: Identified linear model parameters, controller gains and observer gains were selected as shown in Table 1.
Figure 10 represents the accurate trajectory tracking and tracking error in the presence of uncertainties, respectively.

caption.p: The actuator position closely follows the desired trajectory.

sec.p: The proposed approach could estimate the actuator output precisely as shown in Figure 11. Also, In the experiment results the switching functions were replaced by the saturation function which reduce chattering effects.

caption.p: Precise estimation of the actuator position.

sec.p: Finally, Figure 12 depicts the control input is bounded.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The dynamic model of piezoelectric actuators contains the hysteresis non-linearity effect and external forces coupled with a second-order linear dynamic. The generalized Prandtl–Ishlinskii model was used to identify and compensate for the hysteresis effect. Because of contact with the environment, a BHE is induced on the actuator. Considering the position as an only measurable state, a modified sliding observer was used to estimate full states of the actuator. An adaptive perturbation estimation approach was designed to estimate the pure external force instead of expensive force sensors. Base on estimated states and environment force, a sliding mode control was implemented on the actuator to achieve the appropriate trajectory tracking. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed controller based on the estimated states achieved precise trajectory tracking and acceptable external force estimation.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
